nodes.text: A selective instruction duplication technique hardened by identifying and re-prioritizing input-sensitive "incubative" instructions (MINPSID) can mitigate the loss of silent data corruption (SDC) coverage of existing SID methods when programs run with multiple inputs
Existing SID evaluations typically use a single reference input and assume program error resilience is similar across inputs
When protected programs run with different inputs, SDC coverage provided by existing SID can drop substantially compared to the expected coverage measured on the reference input

A small subset of instructions, called incubative instructions, exhibit low SDC probability under the reference input but much higher SDC probability under other inputs and thus cause the observed SDC coverage loss

MINPSID identifies incubative instructions via a guided input search (genetic algorithm) using weighted control-flow graph profiling, runs per-instruction fault injection on discovered inputs, then re-prioritizes those instructions in SID instruction selection
MINPSID is implemented as LLVM passes, automates cost and benefit profiling, input search, re-prioritization, and code transformation for duplication

Root-cause analysis of fault-injection experiments shows incubative instructions were not prioritized by SID because their measured benefit on the reference input was near zero while benefits can be much higher on other inputs

Preliminary fault injection across 11 CPU benchmarks and 50 random inputs each shows average expected SDC coverage dropped from 96.12% to 58.76% when using existing SID across multiple inputs, with extreme per-benchmark drops (e.g., 100% loss in Kmeans)
Across benchmarks, on average 37.58% of inputs lead to SDC coverage loss at target protection levels, with per-benchmark maxima (e.g., 72% in FFT), demonstrating the problem is common
Empirical characterization: incubative instructions constitute on average 15.79% of instructions and are responsible for at least 97% of SDC coverage loss; counts vary per program (6.20% to 32.09%)
MINPSID uses a genetic algorithm with a fitness function based on dynamic weighted control-flow graph differences to prioritize generation of inputs that exercise new execution paths

Per-instruction fault injection (single-bit flips at LLVM IR level using LLFI) on GA-discovered inputs identifies incubative instructions which are assigned conservative upper-bound benefits for knapsack-based SID selection

Evaluation: MINPSID reduces SDC coverage loss compared to baseline SID on 11 benchmarks, mitigating 97% of coverage loss on average and shortening coverage variability across inputs; expected coverage by MINPSID is more conservative but bounds the minimum coverage better

Efficiency: MINPSID finds 45.60% more incubative instructions than a random input search within the time budget and converges earlier; MINPSID average one-time preprocessing cost is 63.71 minutes per benchmark (parallelizable)

Conclusion: MINPSID effectively mitigates SID SDC coverage loss across multiple inputs by identifying and re-prioritizing incubative instructions, at the cost of a one-time analysis overhead and producing more conservative expected coverage
